briefOverview: A plural council of Gods completes creation, sanctifies the seventh time, and establishes human life in Eden with roles, relationships, and a command regarding the tree of knowledge.
summary: The Gods finish the heavens and the earth, choose to rest on the seventh “time,” and sanctify it. They form man from the dust, place his spirit within him, and plant a garden in Eden with every tree, including the tree of life and the tree of knowledge of good and evil. A river flows from Eden and divides into four heads, and the man is put in the garden to dress and keep it. The Gods command the man not to eat from the tree of knowledge, warning of death “in the time” he eats, with Abraham noting this concerns divine time reckoning tied to Kolob and not yet appointed to Adam. Seeing it is not good for man to be alone, the Gods form a woman from his rib; Adam recognizes her as bone of his bones and declares the union of man and wife as one flesh, and both are naked and unashamed. The Gods also form the beasts and birds and bring them to Adam, who names them.
externalContext: This chapter comes from the Book of Abraham, a Latter-day Saint text produced by Joseph Smith in the 19th century and canonized in the Pearl of Great Price. In Abraham, the creation is portrayed as a collaborative act by “the Gods,” reflecting a divine council motif. The narrative uses “times” rather than “days,” suggesting periods or epochs rather than 24-hour days. Kolob, referenced earlier in Abraham 3, is described as a star associated with divine proximity and time reckoning, which frames the remark about Adam not yet having his own appointed reckoning of time. The chapter runs parallel to Genesis 2 while retaining distinctive Latter-day Saint emphases on counsel among the Gods and cosmic time.
externalReferences: The chapter closely parallels Genesis 2:1–25, including the sanctification of the seventh day (Genesis 2:1–3), the formation of man and woman, the garden with the tree of life and the tree of knowledge (Genesis 2:9, 16–17), the fourfold river (Genesis 2:10–14), and Adam’s naming of the animals (Genesis 2:19–20). Its plural language about divine actors resonates with Genesis 1:26–27 (“Let us make man in our image”). The time reference to Kolob relates to Abraham 3:4–9, which discusses differing measures of time in relation to celestial bodies and divine presence. Latter-day Saint readers often compare this account with Moses 3:1–25 (Pearl of Great Price), another expanded creation narrative aligned with Genesis 2.
practicalQuestions: What practices help you treat a weekly period of rest as holy rather than merely vacant time?
In what concrete ways can you “dress and keep” the parts of creation under your care (home, work, community, environment)?
How do you respond to divine or moral boundaries when their full consequences are not immediately visible?
What habits strengthen the “one flesh” unity of marriage or committed partnership?
How might collaborative counsel (modeled by the Gods) improve decision-making in your family, workplace, or community?
uncertainAreas: The precise meaning of “seventh time” and how it maps onto duration is unstated. The relationship between the formation of animals (vv. 20–21) and earlier creative acts can be read sequentially or as a recounting, creating chronological ambiguity. The theological identity of “the Gods” is not defined here. The note about death occurring “after the Lord’s time” and the role of Kolob in time reckoning invites interpretation on how mortality and time apply to Adam prior to the Fall.
